job_title: Customer Service Representative in Claymont, DE
pros: The pro's would be the pay. Considering the minimum wage here in Delaware, Bank of America pays pretty well.
cons:
The work load is terrible. There is always something new being added on to your already long list of task. Management pushes out a few slides for you to read, then wants to label you an expert. The lack of support from management is terrible. Management brushes you off when you have questions, they try to avoid you during crucial times. If you like feeling alone, and not supported BOA is for you !
The work load, and work environment may cause a huge strain on your health, physically , and mentally. I would not recommend BOA to anyone.
During these tough times of a pandemic , incentives were cut. As we were advised we were "abusing" incentives (although we work extremely hard for them) , also yearly bonuses were cut. When we asked management , we were advised there would be no bonus " Considering all that was done for us this year" As if us being allowed to work from home was some sort of privilege. 
Everyday you are shown management does not care about you, only what you can do for them ( Take calls), and that customers are way more important to them than their own employees. Management can be extremely condescending, and flat out disrespectful, not only to you , but to customers at times, as well . 
Truly I would not recommend BOA to anyone, since working here I have experienced several health issues that are work related, and have not been supported at all. 
I suppose there is room to move around within the Bank, and traveling to several different departments. However that is assuming you will be supported. I told my manager that I wanted to branch off to a different department, and was told" she doesn't like to see good employees leave, she'll look into trying to give me a good review" essentially trying to sabotage my career within the bank.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great perks. Great benefits. Great paid time off. Work life balance can be flexible, but can be over extended on time if management needs you. Great annual reviews that actually make a difference with associates. Great roles to transition into with experience. Excellence banking experience for future career growth and career change. Professional work environment.
cons: Overwhelming as you start growing up the ladder. Stress if not managed can eat you alive. I don’t mean this lightly. It can be very overwhelming with such large goals that people are constantly going on leave or taking time off for their mental health. I would say the biggest con is that people tend to not get a lot of one on one attention when it comes to business growth as a individual. Things change so fast that we sometime have managers that don’t invest enough in giving back the information to colleagues which can slow down the adaption of most employees and yet managers then wonder why no one knows what we are aiming for as a business model together in their markets or regions. This can be extremely stressful to those who want to advance and grow rapidly in business which then in turn makes them decide to leave or work on other paths of careers that move a bit quicker.
